newsitem.title: DENMARK: Car bomb goes off in biker gang war, no one hurt.
newsitem.headline: Car bomb goes off in biker gang war, no one hurt.

text.p: A car bomb exploded as a man drove from his home near the northern city of Aalborg on Wednesday, but left him unhurt in the latest round of a motorcycle gang war in Denmark.

Police said the 32-year-old man was a member of the MC Denmark biker gang, affiliated with the Hell's Angels group which is locked in a brutal turf war with rival Bandidos bikers across the Nordic region.
The blast in a parking lot near a residential block left several nearby parked cars shattered. No arrests were made and police bomb experts were investigating the scene of the blast.
Police said they believed the incident was connected with the shooting and wounding on Monday of a Hell's Angel by two armed men in a central Aalborg street.
The biker war has intensified this summer, with sporadic shootings in recent weeks in Denmark, Sweden and Finland.
In July a bag containing explosives was hurled from a fast-moving car at the Danish Hell's Angels headquarters in central Copenhagen, but failed to go off.

A few days later a Danish motorbike gang leader was shot and seriously injured in a night raid by unknown assailants on a prison west of Copenhagen, while a member of the Bandidos biker group was shot and wounded in Helsingborg, south Sweden.

In other incidents, a Finnish Hell's Angels member was beaten up by an unknown intruder in a prison near Helsinki in August, weeks after a Danish member of the Bandidos was shot dead in Drammen, south of the Norwegian capital Oslo.
Investigators say the Bandidos, a Danish offshoot of a Texas-based biker gang, are threatening the California-based Hell's Angels' domination of the Nordic motorcycle fraternity.
Their two-year war has so far claimed six lives.
